title: Barrett decries 'Willie Horton' tactics
content:
Barrett ’ s record is fair game , said Walker in defense of his controverisal ad . Barrett decries 'Willie Horton ' tactics
MILWAUKEE — Democrat Tom Barrett accused Scott Walker of using “ Willie Horton ” style tactics during a caustic final debate Thursday night , chiding the Wisconsin governor for running a negative television ad that includes an image of a dead baby .
“ He ’ s running a commercial right now that shows a dead baby . He shows a picture of a dead baby . This is Willie Horton stuff , ” an exasperated Barrett charged during the one-hour debate at Marquette University . “ You should be ashamed of that commercial Scott Walker . ”
The Walker ad in question shows a blurred picture of a 2-year-old who spent six days in intensive care after being severely beaten . “ But Tom Barrett ’ s police department didn ’ t consider it a violent crime , ” says a narrator .
Walker has made crime statistics in Milwaukee a centerpiece of his closing argument against Barrett in the June 5 gubernatorial recall election , seizing on recent news reports that have identified hundreds of misreported violent crimes during the mayor ’ s tenure .
But Barrett ’ s outrage at the scathing spot created the most emotionally charged moment of the evening .
“ That baby died . The person who killed that baby was arrested by Milwaukee police , was prosecuted by Milwaukee … But you know what they did wrong . After the baby died , they didn ’ t change the code . It was a bureaucratic mistake , ” Barrett explained in front of a live audience . “ And you ’ re running a commercial attacking my integrity , claiming that I had something to do with this , and you know that ’ s false . I ’ ll tell you right now , I had nothing to do with that . ”
Walker defended the core argument in the spot , saying Barrett ’ s record was fair game .
“ Violent crime rate has not gone down . I think if it was worth to say that people should vote for you in the primary because it had gone down , the same question is completely legitimate in reverse . Violent crime has gone up , sadly , ” he replied .
But Barrett appeared to get the best of the exchange , and managed to land a blow that referenced the ongoing criminal investigation into Walker ’ s former aides as a county executive .
“ I have a police department that arrests felons . He has a practice of hiring them , ” charged Barrett .
The heated back-and-forth between Walker and Barrett underscored the heightening tension in a race that Democrats are convinced is closing in the final days .
Following the release of a Marquette University poll showing a 7-point lead for Walker , the Barrett campaign unloaded its own internal survey conducted by Democratic pollster Fred Yang showing only a 2-point deficit .
Democrats are heartened about projections of a heavy turnout topping 2010 levels and argue that the tide has turned in their direction as the argument has increasingly focused on ethical questions clouding Walker ’ s tenure .
On Thursday , a former spokeswoman for Walker became the 13th person to receive immunity in the so-called John Doe criminal probe that has already lead to the indictment of several former Walker aides .
“ We ’ ve complied with everything we ’ ve been asked to do , ” said Walker . “ The reality is , every time the facts come out , they prove what we say . ”
For a moment Thursday , the campaign returned to the issue that sparked the historic recall in the first place .
The two rivals spent the first 15 minutes of the debate sparring over the governor ’ s decision to eliminate collective bargaining rights for public employees .
Walker framed his budget bill as a bold but necessary action taken to get the state ’ s finances in order and pointed to a $ 154 million surplus and the addition of 23,000 jobs this year as evidence his reforms had already produced results .
“ The mayor has said repeatedly throughout the primary he wants go to back and restore collective bargaining , ” Walker noted .
Barrett acknowledged as governor he would restore collective bargaining rights , but pushed back on the assertion that he would be a pawn of the unions .
“ The difference is I ’ ll allow them to be at the table . He doesn ’ t even want to have a conversation with them . They know that I ’ m not a pushover , but the difference is I respect them to be at the table , not to own the table , but to be at the table , ” he said , describing Walker as a “ rock star for the far right ” on a crusade to be the hero of an ideological movement .
“ It ’ s about the tea party movement and what he can do to make this the tea party capital of the country , ” Barrett charged .
The mayor also made the case that if Walker is allowed to remain in office , he ’ ll turn Wisconsin into a right-to work state .
When pressed by the moderator if he would veto right-to-work legislation , Walker hedged .
“ I ’ ve said it ’ s not going to get there . You ’ re asking a hypothetical , ” he replied .
Barrett said voters should read between the lines on that answer .
“ Mark my words , he ’ ll sign it , ” Barrett said . “ He would have a fall from grace with the far right if he would say he ’ s going to veto that . ”
Both campaigns will receive high-profile help on the campaign trail Friday . Former President Bill Clinton will join Barrett for a morning rally at a park in Milwaukee and South Carolina Gov . Nikki Haley will campaign with Walker at a graphics business in Sussex .

( Also on POLITICO: Walker ad on Milwaukee crime statistics)

Walker has made crime statistics in Milwaukee a centerpiece of his closing argument against Barrett in the June 5 gubernatorial recall election, seizing on recent news reports that have identified hundreds of misreported violent crimes during the mayor’s tenure.

“Violent crime rate has not gone down. I think if it was worth to say that people should vote for you in the primary because it had gone down, the same question is completely legitimate in reverse. Violent crime has gone up, sadly,” he replied.

But Barrett appeared to get the best of the exchange, and managed to land a blow that referenced the ongoing criminal investigation into Walker’s former aides as a county executive.

“I have a police department that arrests felons. He has a practice of hiring them,” charged Barrett.

The heated back-and-forth between Walker and Barrett underscored the heightening tension in a race that Democrats are convinced is closing in the final days.

Following the release of a Marquette University poll showing a 7-point lead for Walker, the Barrett campaign unloaded its own internal survey conducted by Democratic pollster Fred Yang showing only a 2-point deficit.

Democrats are heartened about projections of a heavy turnout topping 2010 levels and argue that the tide has turned in their direction as the argument has increasingly focused on ethical questions clouding Walker’s tenure.

Walker framed his budget bill as a bold but necessary action taken to get the state’s finances in order and pointed to a $154 million surplus and the addition of 23,000 jobs this year as evidence his reforms had already produced results.

“The difference is I’ll allow them to be at the table. He doesn’t even want to have a conversation with them. They know that I’m not a pushover, but the difference is I respect them to be at the table, not to own the table, but to be at the table,” he said, describing Walker as a “rock star for the far right” on a crusade to be the hero of an ideological movement.

“It’s about the tea party movement and what he can do to make this the tea party capital of the country,” Barrett charged.

The mayor also made the case that if Walker is allowed to remain in office, he’ll turn Wisconsin into a right-to work state.

When pressed by the moderator if he would veto right-to-work legislation, Walker hedged.

“I’ve said it’s not going to get there. You’re asking a hypothetical,” he replied.

Barrett said voters should read between the lines on that answer.

“Mark my words, he’ll sign it,” Barrett said. “He would have a fall from grace with the far right if he would say he’s going to veto that.”
